definition: surname Mi/name of an ancient state
can/to be possible/to be able to/will/to be likely to/to be sure to/to assemble/to meet/to gather/to see/union/group/association/CL:個|个[ge4]/a moment (Taiwan pr. for this sense is [hui3])

sentences.english: The senate had a session today with closed doors.
sentences.chinese: 參議院今天召開一次祕密會議。

sentences.english: But Chinese leaders believe such dialogue belongs behind closed doors.
sentences.chinese: 但是中國領導人認爲，這種對話屬於祕密會晤。

sentences.english: The visitor opened the wrong door and broke in on  a private conference.
sentences.chinese: 那名來訪者開錯了門，突然擾亂了一個祕密會議。

sentences.english: Free to enter their conclave at will.
sentences.chinese: 隨意自由的進入他們的祕密會議。

sentences.english: The committee had an underground meeting and was unanimous to fire him.
sentences.chinese: 委員會召開祕密會議並一致通過解僱他。

sentences.english: Clandestine meetings were held in parking lots and diners.
sentences.chinese: 祕密會議在停車場和餐廳舉行。

sentences.english: This non-party attitude is most seen in closed meetings .
sentences.chinese: 這種不分黨派的態度，最常見於祕密會議中。

sentences.english: Full details of the secret meeting have emerged in an article in Fortune.
sentences.chinese: 密會的詳情已在《財富》的一篇文章中予以披露。

sentences.english: 'Even the term 'huddles' sounds suspicious, ' he said.
sentences.chinese: 他說，甚至連“祕密會議”這個詞聽起來都可疑。

sentences.english: And that he knows when the next super-secret meeting is.
sentences.chinese: 而且他知道下次祕密會議的召開緣由。

sentences.english: There is always an aura of mystery to the conclaves of medical men.
sentences.chinese: 醫學界人士的祕密會議總有一種神祕的氣氛。

sentences.english: A conclave of cardinals was held to elect the new Pope.
sentences.chinese: 紅衣主教團舉行了祕密會議來選舉新教皇。

definition: widely spread/widely rumored/stories abound/(sb's exploits are) widely circulated
two simultaneous happy events in the family
The Sun (the name of various newspapers, notably in the UK and in Hong Kong)
Sun Jian (155-191), famous general at end of Han dynasty, forerunner of the southern kingdom of Wu of the Three Kingdoms
lit. kept inside a drum (idiom)/fig. completely in the dark
Chiang Wei-kuo (1916-1997), adopted son of Chiang Kai-shek 蔣介石|蒋介石
to put forward plans and ideas (also derogatory)/to give advice (idiom)
